String:
<Universe>

The universe encompasses all celestial bodies, space itself, and time, which includes the entire history of the universe. In other words, the universe incorporates time as an element and is not constrained by it.

<Observable Universe>

The size of the observable universe, as seen from Earth, has a radius of 46.5 billion light-years, making a total of 93 billion light-years.

<You Can Go Too>

Scientists from NASA-founded private companies like Golden Spike Company are planning a lunar landing package. It is a two-person team staying on the moon for two days, with a cost of $750 million per person, which is approximately $1.3 billion.

<The Moon is Moving Away>

The moon is receding from Earth at a rate of 4 cm per year, roughly the speed at which our nails grow. But don’t worry. The sun will explode before the moon moves far enough to cause concern.

<The Traveling Sun>

The sun is traveling at a speed of 230 km per second, meaning the entire solar system is on a journey. It takes about 225 million years for the sun to complete one orbit of the Milky Way.

<A Day Lasting Two Months>

A day on Mercury lasts 1,408 hours.

<This Happens When the Ozone Layer is Destroyed>

Mercury is closer to the sun and thought to be the hottest, but Venus is actually the hottest planet in the solar system.

<Earth Wins at Last>

There are more trees on Earth than stars in the Milky Way. The Milky Way has 100-400 billion stars, while Earth has over 3 trillion trees.

<Sorry, Moon>

We don’t live on the moon yet, but we’ve left nearly 200 tons of trash on its surface, including hammers, shovels, wet wipes, and empty space food packages.

<Mars < Oceans>

We know more about Mars and the moon than we do about our oceans. Mars and the moon are 99% mapped, but only 5% of Earth’s oceans have been mapped.

<Jupiter>

Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system by mass. Its mass is 2.5 times greater than that of all other planets combined.

<A Planet That Floats in Water>

Saturn is the only planet in the solar system that can float in water. Despite being the second-largest planet, it is the lightest in terms of density.

<The Mystery of Gas Giants>

Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune are gas giants and lack solid surfaces, making it impossible to land a spacecraft. However, they are believed to have small rocky cores relative to their size.

<Neptune>

Neptune was the first planet discovered using mathematics. It can only be observed optically. A year on Neptune is equivalent to 164.8 Earth years.

<The Color of the Sun>

We often think of the sun as red or orange, but this is incorrect. The sun is a mix of all colors, and if seen from space, it would appear white. The sun is fundamentally white.

<Footprints That Last Forever>

There’s no wind on the moon, so footprints there can last for millions of years unless future astronauts step on them.

<Neptune: Late Discovery, Slow Orbit>

Discovered in 1846, Neptune completed only one orbit of the sun by 2011.

<Moon Dust>

Inhaling moon dust can damage DNA and cause cell death. If moon dust is around, don’t forget your mask.

<Study Vocabulary Instead>

The latest smartphone you’re holding is millions of times more powerful than the computers used for the Apollo program. But you’re just playing games with it...

<Visiting the Solar System>

Humanity has been exploring space for over 60 years, during which our spacecraft have visited all planets in the solar system, including dwarf planets.

<Between the Moon and Earth>

When the Moon is at its farthest point from Earth,
all the planets in the solar system can fit
between the Moon and Earth.

<Surprisingly Beautiful in Photos>

Mars is called the Red Planet, but its sunsets
are blue. This is due to the dust in the Martian
atmosphere, which allows blue light to
pass through more effectively than red light.

<Moon Walkers>

So far, only 12 people have walked on the Moon's
surface, all of whom were American astronauts.

<Venus's Rotation>

Venus has an extremely slow rotation,
so one day on Venus lasts 243 Earth days.

<Specifically Raspberry Scent>

The center of the galaxy is said to smell fruity.
Scientists have found large amounts of ethyl
formate in the gas clouds at the galaxy's center,
a chemical compound known for its fruity scent.

<It's Often Mistaken for a Star>

The International Space Station is the largest
human-made object in space and the third
brightest object in the night sky.

<90000000000 : 50>

The Sun produces 90 billion megatons of energy
every second. In comparison, the Tsar Bomba,
the most powerful hydrogen bomb in history,
had a yield of 50 megatons.

<Earth>

Earth is the only planet in the solar system
not named after a deity. The most widely
accepted theory is that its name originates
from ancient Germanic words for 'ground' or 'soil.'

<Look it Up if You're Curious>

The front and back sides of the Moon look
different. The backside is notably less attractive.

<Surface Tension>

In space, liquids form spheres due to surface
tension, which minimizes the surface area.

<It Takes 8 Minutes at Light Speed>

It takes sunlight 8 minutes and 20 seconds
to reach Earth.

<Paper Thickness>

If you fold an A4 sheet 42 times, its thickness
would exceed the distance from Earth to the Moon.
But you'll struggle to fold it more than 8 times.

<Coca-Cola>

Coca-Cola was the first commercial drink
consumed in space.

<The Silent Universe>

Sound requires air to travel, but space is a
vacuum, making it completely silent. Even if
you shout right next to someone, they won't hear you.

<Where Does Space Begin?>

Space is defined as starting 100 km above Earth,
according to the international Kármán Line standard.

<The Force of Gravity>

Gravity can bend light, meaning that the
objects astronomers observe may not
appear exactly as they are.

<The First Spacefaring Dog>

The first living creature to travel to space
was a dog named 'Laika.' On November 3, 1957,
Laika boarded the Soviet spacecraft Sputnik 2
but died within hours due to heat and stress.

<Space Pens>

Normal pens don't work in space due to
the lack of gravity, which prevents ink
from flowing downward. Astronauts use
specially designed pens instead.

<Space Cockroaches>

A Russian cockroach named Hope gave birth to
12 offspring during a 33-day space journey.
These baby cockroaches were found to be
stronger and faster than their Earth-bound counterparts.

<Space Welding>

In the absence of oxygen, uncoated pieces
of metal in space can permanently fuse together.

<But we will part completely around 2030>

 Voyager 1 is the farthest human-made object from Earth.
Its instruments should have stopped functioning long ago,
but for some unknown reason, they are still operational.

<Gliese 581c>

Gliese 581c, known for its Earth-like environment, is considered the most likely planet to host life. In 2008, a signal was sent, and a reply from potential intelligent life could arrive by 2048.

<Jupiter's Eye>

Can you see Jupiter's Eye at the bottom of the planet?
Inside, there is a massive high-pressure vortex swirling.
That vortex is larger than Earth.
If you're curious, go back and take another look!

<The Size of the Sun>

 The Sun accounts for 99.8% of the total mass of the solar system
and is so huge that 1 million Earths could fit inside it.

<The Only Time Traveler>

 Russian cosmonaut Sergei Krikalev holds the record for
the only time traveler. He spent a long time in orbit
around Earth, and as a result, he has lived 0.02 seconds
less than other people on Earth. In essence,
he traveled 0.02 seconds into his own future.

<Cosmic Communication>

 On the night of August 15, 1977, Professor Jerry Ehman
received a radio signal from space. No one knows where
or how it came from.

<Elliptical Earth>

 Earth is not a perfect sphere.
Due to centrifugal forces pushing outward at the equator,
the term 'oblate spheroid' is more accurate.

<Grateful for the Magnetic Field>

 Earth's magnetic field acts as a shield against
the constant bombardment of high-energy particles from the Sun,
helps some animals navigate, and allows us to use compasses.

<Hot and Cold>

 The highest temperature ever recorded on Earth's surface
was 136°F, and the lowest was -128.6°F.

<Moonquakes>

 The Moon also experiences quakes,
which can influence tidal intervals
and potentially impact Earth.

<The Perks of Space Travel>

 Astronauts can grow about 5cm taller in space.
With reduced gravity, the discs between their vertebrae expand.
Of course, they return to their original height
once back on Earth.

<The Drawbacks of Space Travel 1>

 Astronauts returning from space face weakened immune systems, higher cancer risk, vision changes from eye pressure, cognitive decline, and increased anemia risk due to severe red blood cell destruction.

<The Drawbacks of Space Travel 2>

 A study on 17 astronauts found that even 12 months
after returning from space, their bone strength and mineral density
decreased by 2%. This is equivalent to at least
ten years of bone loss. It seems space is not meant for humans.

<Atoms 1>

 Atoms are 99.999999999% empty space.
The phone you hold, your chair, bed, and even you
and the universe are mostly not there.

<Odds of Finding a Lost Item in Space>

 On the second day of Apollo 16's lunar mission,
pilot Ken Mattingly lost his wedding ring. Nine days later,
he managed to spot it floating outside the door,
making him the only person to find a lost wedding ring in space.

<Is This a Coincidence...?>

 The Moon is 400 times smaller than the Sun,
but it's also 400 times closer to Earth.
This is why the Moon and the Sun appear the same size in the sky.
Thanks to this astonishing coincidence,
we can witness total solar eclipses.

<The Diamond Planet>

 Scientists suggest that the planet 55 Cancri e, 40 light-years away, may have a mass three times Earth's, entirely made of diamonds. If true, it would hold diamonds worth $26.9 quintillion.

<Origin of the Black Hole>

 The term 'black hole' was not coined by an astronomer. It originated by chance when physicist John Wheeler was looking for a replacement for 'gravitationally collapsed object,' and someone in the audience suggested 'black hole' during a conference.

<Try This Challenge>

 Any object can become a black hole if you compress it
below its Schwarzschild radius. For example, compressing the Sun
to the size of a small town or the Earth to the size of a peanut
would achieve this.

<I Didn't Eat It>

 Black holes don't suck in matter.
Matter falls into black holes just as an apple
falls to the ground due to Earth's gravity.

<Realistic Depiction>

 The planets orbiting in the background of the
starting screen are animated based on
realistic orbital speed ratios.

<The Cosmic Prison>

 At the edge of a black hole lies the 'event horizon,'
where nothing can return once crossed—not even light.
Since nothing moves faster than light, this means
nothing can escape the event horizon once it's crossed.

<Secrets of the Universe>

 We still don't know what happens inside black holes. It's likely that something there will contradict our current scientific theories. Understanding what occurs inside could potentially change everything we know about the universe.

<This Is the Universe...>

 The universe contains more stars than grains of sand on Earth.
The number of stars visible through telescopes is estimated
to be about 700 quintillion.

<I Believe So>

 It's obvious, but Earth is the only planet in this vast universe
known to have life. It's truly remarkable, isn't it?
